title: Photographer tells how he captured Haiti shooting incident
text:
Image copyright Reuters Image caption Andres Martinez Casares is behind the lens as Senator Jean Marie Ralph Féthière wields his gun

Andres Martinez Casares, the Reuters photographer who took the dramatic pictures of Haitian Senator Jean-Marie Ralph Féthière opening fire outside the country's parliament on Monday, tells the BBC how he reacted to being caught up in the incident.

Image copyright Reuters

Mr Féthière opened fire as he left parliament in the capital, Port-au-Prince, claiming he was defending himself from protesters.

"I followed a group of opposition supporters who went to the [car park] of the Haitian Senate and parliament and I saw them shouting at Féthière, who got into the car," Martinez said.

"I moved to the side as I thought they could drive aggressively to leave.

"But some men went to the door and started shouting again, and then Féthière came out and pointed the gun in the air and fired some shots, and then [fired] to the ground."

Image copyright Reuters

"It was a matter of a few seconds, my pictures were taken in two or three [seconds]; there was just enough time to go from one side of the car to the other and frame some quick pictures."

Martinez says he puts the fact he managed to remain calm and still take pictures down to experience.

"I don't think you are totally calm because you are alert, trying to be aware of the whole situation; there is a man shooting in the air, but there are also scared people running away that push you, and you don't know if there [is] anybody else willing to use a gun.

"You are there, and there is an unusual event in front of you that might not last, you just try to get something in focus to be able to show it to the world."

Although he did not fear for his life, Martinez said he "was concerned that the situation could get worse".

Image copyright Reuters

Chery Dieu-Nalio, a photographer for the Associated Press, was hit in the face.

"I've known Chery for a long time," Martinez said.

After the shooting, "he came calling me and pointing to his chin, so when I saw the blood, I checked him and I stopped the bleeding with a bandage. If you want to help, you have to keep yourself focused and in relative calm, otherwise you can't think clearly."

Image copyright Reuters

Later, Martinez said he went to the hospital to check on Dieu-Nalio.

"He was sent home after the doctors took care of him. He was resting and waiting to have the bullet removed. The doctors said that he was fine, and his condition wasn't life-threatening, so they sent him back home to be with his family."

Image copyright Reuters

Earlier, Martinez captured Senator Willot Joseph as he scuffled with opposition supporters upon arriving at the Congress building in Port-au-Prince.

Image copyright Reuters

"I've covered shootings before and have also photographed fights in official buildings, like in the National Assembly in Caracas in 2017 or recently in the Haitian parliament between lawmakers, but I never thought that I would see a politician using a gun like [Monday]."

Image copyright Reuters Image caption Mr Joseph holds a gun as he pushes an opposition supporter who was shouting at him

All pictures copyright.
description: Andres Martinez Casares describes how he reacted as a senator started shooting outside parliament.
